p: In in vitro/vivo studies, the aqueous extract of E. macrophyllus exhibited strong antinflammatory activities by decreasing rats paw edema, inflammatory exudates, infiltrate tissues, NO production, LTB4 release, and neutrophil migration [ 222]. In preclinical studies, the methanolic extract of E. macrophyllus was not cytotoxic, genotoxic, mutagenic, and no acute toxicity (up to the maximum dose of 2000 mg/kg b.w.) has been observed in tested animals [ 221]. However, the extrapolation of animal experiments to clinical practice must be done with caution [ 223].
